results.headline: Review: In ‘10.000 km,’ Lovers an Ocean Apart Struggle to Connect
results.summary_short: Carlos Marques-Marcet’s film about a couple’s shift to a long-distance relationship looks at the role technology plays in negotiating absence.

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of 10,000 KM

results.headline: Review: ‘Do I Sound Gay?’ Examines a Manner of Speaking
results.summary_short: This documentary, written and directed by David Thorpe, dissects the stereotype of the so-called gay voice.

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of Do I Sound Gay?

results.headline: Review: ‘Stray Dog’ Documents a Complex Veteran
results.summary_short: This film, directed by Debra Granik, details how a Vietnam veteran defies simple symbols and challenges lazy thinking about ideology.

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of Stray Dog

results.headline: Review: ‘Amy,’ an Intimate Diary of Amy Winehouse’s Rise and Destruction
results.summary_short: Asif Kapadia’s documentary is a harrowing look at the singer’s life that drives home the costs of celebrity and fandom.

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of Amy

results.headline: Review: ‘Stung’ Stars Giant Wasps That Attack the Rich
results.summary_short: In Benni Diez’s horror comedy, a millionaire’s al fresco dinner turns ugly because her growth-hormone-infused plant fertilizer has created a swarm of monsters.

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of Stung

results.headline: Review: ‘Jimmy’s Hall’ Pits the Church Against a Populist Gathering Place
results.summary_short: Ken Loach’s film, set in Ireland in the 1930s, centers on a man of the people who turns an abandoned community center into a place to dance and dream.

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of Jimmy's Hall

results.headline: Review: In ‘Zarafa,’ a Giraffe Journeys in a Hot-Air Balloon
results.summary_short: This story of a friendship between a boy and a wild creature takes them across the Mediterranean.

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of Zarafa

results.headline: Review: In ‘Jackie & Ryan,’ a Handsome Drifter Guides the Way
results.summary_short: Ami Canaan Mann’s film portrays a romance between a singer who fled her marriage for her hometown in Utah and an itinerant musician who arrives there on the back of a freight train.

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of Jackie & Ryan

results.headline: Review: In ‘Cartel Land’ Documentary, Vigilantes Wage Drug Wars
results.summary_short: Matthew Heineman’s on-the-ground film profiles leaders of two vigilante groups fighting drug gangs, one in Arizona and the other in Michoacán, Mexico.

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of Cartel Land

results.headline: Review: ‘Closer to God’ Offers a Modern-Day Frankenstein Tale
results.summary_short: Billy Senese’s new film explores the consequences of a doctor’s experiments in human cloning.

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of Closer to God

results.headline: Review: ‘Magic Mike XXL,’ Fleshing Out a Sequel With Heart as Well as Pecs and Abs
results.summary_short: Channing Tatum returns in this comedy, which transports the audience to a world of sexual intrigue that feels as safe and wholesome as a child’s birthday party.

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of Magic Mike XXL

results.headline: Review: In ‘Terminator Genisys,’ Ageless Cyborgs and a Deathless Franchise
results.summary_short: Arnold Schwarzenegger returns, it’s 1984 again, and Sarah Connor is at risk once more.

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of Terminator: Genisys

results.headline: Review: ‘Mala Mala’ Shares Experiences of Being Transgender in Puerto Rico
results.summary_short: The directors of this documentary, Dan Sickles and Antonio Santini, interview prostitutes, drag queens, small-business owners and activists about their transitions and relationships.

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of Mala Mala

results.headline: Review: ‘A Poem Is a Naked Person’ Is a Jam Session of a Documentary
results.summary_short: Les Blank’s film, made in the early 1970s and now receiving a United States theatrical release, looks at the mystery of Leon Russell.
results.display_title: A Poem Is a Naked Person

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of A Poem Is a Naked Person

results.headline: Review: In ‘A Little Chaos,’ a Guileless Kate Winslet Offsets a Lavish Versailles
results.summary_short: Ms. Winslet plays a gardener well ahead of her time in this Louis XIV-era costume drama directed by and starring Alan Rickman.

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of A Little Chaos

results.headline: Review: In ‘A Borrowed Identity,’ Hearts Torn Between 2 Worlds in Israel
results.summary_short: Eran Riklis’s film charts the struggles of an Arab-Israeli teenager making his way in an elite boarding school in Jerusalem.

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of A Borrowed Identity

results.headline: Review: ‘Fresh Dressed’ Follows Hip-Hop From the Streets to the Runway
results.summary_short: This documentary charts how hip-hop fashion initially absorbed what was around it, and then eventually became the inspiration for everyone else.

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of Fresh Dressed

results.headline: Review: ‘Big Game’ Stars Samuel L. Jackson as a President in Dire Straits
results.summary_short: In this adventure, a Scandinavian teenager encounters the American president, who has bailed out of a doomed Air Force One over the Finnish woods.

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of Big Game

results.headline: Review: ‘The Midnight Swim’ Investigates a Mother’s Watery Death
results.summary_short: Sarah Adina Smith’s chiller about three sisters at a lakeside home has one foot in its genre and one in a whole other place.

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of The Midnight Swim

results.headline: Review: ‘The Little Death’ Plays With Narrative Form and Fetish
results.summary_short: Josh Lawson’s polite sex comedy has the soul of a sitcom.
